abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Industrial Finance
            and Development Project for Cote d'Ivoire was
            unsatisfactory. The project only achieved some of its
            objectives, institutional development was modest,
            sustainability is unlikely, and the performance of the Bank
            was marginally satisfactory while the Borrower's was
            unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, Government commitment should be firm and
            clear of ambiguities. Second, the number of parties involved
            in the processing of appraisal reports should be minimized
            to avoid delays. Third, the project appraisal capacity of
            institutions assisting industrial enterprises should be
            strong enough to prevent unrealistic assumptions. Fourth, if
            commercial banks will be utilizing IBRD financing, their
            capacity to analyze long-term investments and their economic
            impact will need to be reinforced. Fifth, the Bank should
            make sure that the Borrower has adequate capacity to manage
            this type of project. Sixth, the level of Bank supervision
            should be evenly maintained throughout project
            implementation in order to respond immediately to rising
            problems. Finally, given the fact that a revised audit on
            this project has not yet been sent to the Bank, the Bank
            should use its leverage to impress upon the Borrower the
            importance of complying with this financial covenant.
